TitleMain.Title: Clinical laboratory waste management (approved guideline)
TitleMain.OtherInformation: / G. A. Hoeltge, P. G. Pollock, P. A. Reinhardt.

Author.CollectiveName: National Committee for Clinical Laboratory Standards.

Abstract.AbstractText: GP5-A, Clinical Laboratory Waste Management; Approved Guideline, was written for use by laboratory managers and is intended to provide approaches to controlling laboratory-generated hazardous and nonhazardous waste. A brief summary of the relevant federal regulations and laws is included. The types of waste addressed include chemical, infectious, radioactive, sharps, and nonhazardous. Options for handling, packaging, labeling, storing, treating, transporting, and disposal of each type of waste is also described.

TitleMain.Title: ERISA : a federal regulatory roadblock to state health care reform

Author.OtherInformation: Popham, Haik, Schnobrich & Kaufman Ltd., Minneapolis, Minnesota.

Author.CollectiveName: Group Health Association of America.
Group Health Institute

Abstract.AbstractText: In the wake of a new administration, speculation abounds about how quickly federal health care legislation will be enacted. In the interim, many states continue to act as "laboratories" for health care reform by designing and implementing reform measures independent of federal action. However, the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 ("ERISA"), 29 U.S.C. Section 1001 et seq., proposes a major roadblock to health care reform by immobilizing many state initiatives. Although legislation has been proposed that would grant ERISA waivers to state health care reform laws, such legislation has not yet been successful. This paper examines the general background and application of ERISA; discusses the impact ERISA has had on various state health care reform measures; analyzes one state's attempt to avoid ERISA preemption; and summarizes proposed legislation that attempts to eliminate the ERISA roadblock.

TitleMain.Title: O processo Hermano de Pina : subsídios para a história da fome, e não só, em Cabo Verde
Violence against women : addressing a global problem.

Author.CollectiveName: Ford Foundation. Women's Program Forum.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: This paper is a compilation of the experiences and ideas discussed during a seminar entitled "Violence Against Women: Addressing a Global Problem," held in New York in February 1991. The seminar was sponsored by the Women's Program Forum, a staff group that provides opportunities for grantmakers to discuss issues related to women's programs. In this paper, the context of the seminar, which reflected the issue that violence against women knows no boundaries in culture, race, or class, were presented. Violence was underscored as perhaps the single greatest cause of injury to women in several countries. A diverse group of researchers and activists focusing primarily on two strategic approaches, community responses to violence against women, and reforms in the criminal justice system was featured.

TitleMain.Title: AIDS and prisons : testimony from a professional experience

TitleOther.TitleAlternate: Scientific publication - Pan American Health Organization ; no. 530
Scientific publication - Pan American Health Organization ;

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Washington, D.C., Pan American Health Organization [PAHO], 1992.
PublicationInfo.Place: Washington, D.C., Pan American Health Organization [PAHO],

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: HIV screening began in Guatemalan prisons in 1988, and 7 inmate carriers were found. 4 cases were discovered in 1989 and 12 cases in March and April 1990. Of these 23 inmates, 1 had died; 3 were imprisoned; 1 was released through exceptional application of work-release parole (he was granted clemency because of his disease); and 19 inmates had been released after serving their time or because their imprisonment was unfounded. Although the number of cases recorded from 1988 to 1990 was minimal for an inmate population of between 6000 and 7000 persons, the 12 cases encountered in March and April of 1990 was alarming. One AIDS death had occurred in Guatemala's penal facilities. The public health institutions denied the inmate the right to be admitted for treatment, and he was denied the request to die at liberty. Motivated by this experience, a meeting of prison doctors and technical specialists was convened in July 1989, at which it was suggested that they organize AIDS education workshops for everyone involved in prison life and draw up plans for preparing prisoners for the results of their HIV tests. Between January and July, two seminars were held for the prison population and the community with support from the National AIDS Commission and PAHO. During the first seminar, recommendations of the Workshop-Seminar on Unification of Legal Efforts against AIDS were reviewed, their errors detected, and recommendations made with regard to confidentiality, treatment, work, mass detection testing, mandatory testing, isolation, training and education, and death with dignity. At a second seminar, some other recommendations were made relating to training of the technical team, time of notification, right to confidentiality, and case publicity. Prison policies involve formulating strategies on prevention, the eradication of prejudices, recognizing the inmate's right to decide whether to be in isolation, and suspending punishment in the terminal phase of the disease.

TitleMain.Title: El SIDA y la poblacion carcelaria : factores de riesgo
TitleMain.OtherInformation: / I. Gonzalez Paez, M.L. Duque de Vasquez, L.M. Babativa de Gonzalez.

TitleOther.TitleAlternate: AIDS and the prison population : risk factors.

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Washington, D.C., Pan American Health Organization [PAHO], 1992.
PublicationInfo.Place: Washington, D.C., Pan American Health Organization [PAHO],

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: 600 male and female inmates in six prisons in Bogota were interviewed about behaviors that could constitute risk factors for AIDS, as a step in development of an educational campaign. The female researchers for the Latin American Research Center in Bogota had some difficulty gaining access to the inmates because the prison administrators were concerned about possible reactions to their presence. The researchers found that the living conditions in the prison made inmates vulnerable to HIV infection. High risk sexual practices, crowding, poor health conditions, absence of health education concerning prevention of sexually transmitted diseases and AIDS, and lack of access to condoms place the population at high risk.

NLMCatalogRecord.Host: A portfolio of AIDS / STD behavioral interventions and research, edited by Lydia S. Bond

TitleMain.Title: San Juan AIDS Institute. Case management for HIV-positive released prisoners. Outline for training case managers

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Los Angeles, California, Peer Education Program of Los Angeles, 1992.
PublicationInfo.Place: Los Angeles, California, Peer Education Program of Los Angeles,

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: An outline is presented for the training of case managers who will help HIV-seropositive released prisoners in Puerto Rico to acquire the skills, knowledge, and communication strategies needed to reduce the transmission of HIV to other individuals. The project will reach 50-75 inmates per month with one trained case manager. The outline first describes the case manager's responsibilities, then goes over the basics of HIV/AID, early intervention, secondary prevention, resources available in San Juan and Puerto Rico, the management of HIV disease, the management of HIV-related symptoms, and communication strategies. Particularly comprehensive information is given on nutrition and self care for individuals infected with HIV.

TitleMain.Title: A KABP study and linked information, education, and communication activities in the Centrale Penitentaire Inrichting at Santo Boma, Suriname.

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Washington, D.C., Pan American Health Organization [PAHO], 1992.
PublicationInfo.Place: Washington, D.C., Pan American Health Organization [PAHO],

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: Prison populations may contain a disproportionate number of individuals who have been at risk of contracting HIV prior to incarceration. These individuals include IV drug users, male and female prostitutes, and sex offenders. IV drug use and equipment sharing, sexual activity involving penetrative anal intercourse, and tattooing and ear piercing involving shared needles are some of the practices in prisons which can facilitate the spread of HIV and other sexually transmitted diseases (STD). Suriname has an inmate population of approximately 1200 males and females. Its two main prisons, Centrale Penitentaire Inrichting (CPI) and the prison at Nickerie, have capacities of 320 and 70 inmates, respectively. 16 inmates were randomly selected in 1990 for detailed interviews to gather information about risky behavior in the CPI; obtain information about attitudes, beliefs, and behavior patterns regarding AIDS/STDs among inmates; and use that information in developing IEC activities throughout the prison directed at inmates and prison wards. The participants stated that IV drugs were not used in the CPI; inmates had poor knowledge about AIDS; the majority of sexual intercourse in the prison involved anal penetration; a convict code exists relating to the sexual use and abuse of newcomers; and prison warders had inadequate knowledge about risky activities with regard to AIDS/STDs. IEC activities were planned and implemented June 1991. 12 inmates and 12 prison warders at different levels were being trained as AIDS/STD educators effective January 1992, a training manual was written in Dutch, and two information leaflets were created in Sranan by inmates. One leaflet focuses upon the situation in the CPI and is meant for distribution among newcomers to Suriname's two main prisons, while the second leaflet contains general information on AIDS and is directed toward the prison population. The leaflets are being pre-tested among inmates before their widespread distribution throughout the two prisons and 19 cell houses. IEC activities will focus upon an "AIDS/STD Information Week" in the CPI to be held in the second half of March 1992. The trained AIDS/STD educators will educate their peers in groups of 15-20 inmates, with the activity beginning with a film on AIDS to be shown to the entire prison population. A counseling unit will be established in close cooperation with the prison medical services, with counseling performed by trained National AIDS Program counselors. Another KABP survey will be conducted after this first wave of IEC activities.

TitleMain.Title: Caring for children--counting the costs

TitleOther.TitleAlternate: Discussion paper series (University of York. Centre for Health Economics) ;

Author.CollectiveName: University of York. Centre for Health Economics.

PublicationInfo.Imprint: York : University of York, Centre for Health Economics, 1992.
PublicationInfo.Publisher: University of York, Centre for Health Economics,

Abstract.AbstractText: Children who come into care of Local Authorities are likely to have significantly poorer health status than other children. Foster carers play an increasingly important role as substitute families for such children, a valuable but scarce resource that is costly to recruit and retain. Despite their status as co-professional members of an extended social work team, foster carers are typically not paid for the work they do. Allowances intended to cover costs incurred in looking after a child are paid, but these vary widely across the country. Many foster carers receive less than 55 British pounds sterling per week (the average kennel fees for looking after a dog), for the children in their care. The present method of calculating these allowances is based on a complex procedure which is difficult for carers to understand or challenge. A simpler method is required and this paper sets out one such costing framework. Reimbursing foster carers for their costs is only a start--increased demand for their valuable skills dictates that sooner or later they will also be rewarded for their work.

TitleMain.Title: Hospital safety : emergency preparedness

Author.CollectiveName: Health & Sciences Network.

PhysicalDescription.Extent: 1 videocassette (14 min., 19 sec.) : sd., col. ; 1/2 in.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: Whether it faces a hurricane, earthquake, or highway chemical spill, your hospital must have a plan for a disaster that meets JCAHO requirements in providing continuous quality care. The influx of patients could put the hospital and its employees under extreme stress; whether the disaster is internal or external, your hospital needs to be prepared. This video explains the hospital's responsibility during a disaster and stresses the importance of a plan that includes actual procedures for each department and employee, along with adequate employee education to meet the plan's requirements.

TitleMain.Title: Can family planning services be delivered in time of war? : The case of Lebanon.

Author.CollectiveName: Lebanon Family Planning Association.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: Addressing the question of whether family planning services can be delivered in time of war, this paper presents the case of the Lebanon Family Planning Association (LFPA), which managed to provide services throughout Lebanon's 16 year civil war. Through in-depth interviews and surveys of LFPA's staff and board members, the paper examines the following issues: 1) What is it like to deliver family planning services during war? 2) Which of the war's conditions were most disruptive? 3) What management approaches made it possible to continue offering services? 4) What were the "buffers" that helped LFPA cope with the war's hardships? And 5) what advice do the respondents offer to other organizations in similar circumstances? Founded in 1969, LFPA is an IPPF affiliate that serves 60,000 clients annually through network of 75 clinics and 175 community health care workers. The war posed LFPA a number of challenges, such as ensuring the safety of its staff, manifesting political neutrality, and maintaining proper medical follow-up and management of complications. Additionally, population displacements, economic difficulties, transportation problems, and communication difficulties also disrupted LFPA services. Nonetheless, LFPA was able to provide services. Interviews with staff members revealed that the main factors that made it possible to cope with the situation were: the "feeling that you must go on," the respect that LFPA had gained in the community, the even greater need for family planning services, and the solidarity among staff and board members. For other family planning organizations facing the prospects of war, those interviewed urged decentralization of services, close contact with clients, and determination.

TitleMain.Title: The Declaration of Principles for Activities Following the Detection of Extraterrestrial Intelligence
TitleMain.OtherInformation: / J. Billingham, M. Michaud, J. Tarter.

Author.CollectiveName: International Symposium on Bioastronomy

Investigator.Affiliation: ARC NASA Ames Research Center, Moffett Field, California 94035, USA.

Abstract.AbstractText: As the science and technology of the Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence (SETI) has slowly emerged over the last thirty years, so there has been a gradually increasing interest in examining the consequences of the detection of a signal transmitted by another civilization. As a result of many years of discussion in the SETI Committee of the International Academy of Astronautics (IAA), a SETI "Post-Detection Protocol" was drawn up as a draft international document. After many revisions, a final document entitled "Declaration of Principles Following the Detection of Extraterrestrial Intelligence" was approved by the International Academy of Astronautics and the International Institute of Space Law. The genesis and scope of this document are presented in the paper. Attention is drawn to the importance of unambiguous international confirmation that the signal is indeed of extraterrestrial intelligent origin, on proper dissemination of the details of the discovery, on procedures for reporting and archiving the data, and on not sending replies without adequate international consultation. This last topic will be the subject for the development of a second "Declaration of Principles", which will address questions dealing with decisions on the preparation and content of a return signal. These questions are discussed.

NLMCatalogRecord.Host: Heidmann J, Klein MJ, eds. Bioastronomy: the search for extraterrestrial life--the exploration broadens

TitleMain.Title: Spouses and children of disabled elders : how large a constituency for long term care reform

Author.CollectiveName: United States. Agency for Health Care Policy and Research.

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Rockville, MD : Agency for Health Care Policy and Research, 1991.
PublicationInfo.Publisher: Agency for Health Care Policy and Research,

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: The purpose of the article is to describe the population potentially affected by long-term care policy as family members-both the larger population of immediate kin who are potential caregivers and the smaller population of active caregivers. Specifically, the article estimates the number of person in the United States who are spouses or children of disabled elders, describes their characteristics, and compares them to the entire United States population. The article then estimates the number of spouses and children who actually give care and estimates the prevalence of caregiving among age groups. Finally, it estimates the size of the population affected most intensely, i.e., active caregivers who have competing responsibilities for child care or employment.

TitleMain.Title: Design and evaluation of a prospective payment system for ambulatory care. Final rept

Author.CollectiveName: 3M Health Information Systems.
United States. Health Care Financing Administration. Office of Research and Demonstrations.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: The report presents the development of a Prospective Payment System (PPS) for the facility cost of outpatient care. The study was required by the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act (OBRA) of 1986 in which Congress directed the Health Care Financing Administration to develop such a system. The Act called for the design and modeling of a PPS for all hospital outpatient services (e.g., same day surgery units, emergency rooms, outpatient clinics, etc.). The faculty cost refers to the hospital cost for providing care (e.g., room charges, medical and surgical supplies, etc.) and excludes the physician's professional service. As part of the research a new ambulatory patient classification system was developed. The new system is referred to as Ambulatory Patient Groups (APGs) and was designed to be the basis of payment in the outpatient PPS. The APGs are a patient classification scheme designed to explain the amount and type of resources used in an ambulatory visit.

TitleMain.Title: Report to Congress on evaluation of nursing education projects funded under Title VII of the Public Health Service Act. Final rept

Author.CollectiveName: Levine Associates, Inc.
United States. Health Resources and Services Administration. Division of Nursing.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: Title VII of the Public Health Service Act provides for a comprehensive set of nursing education programs. The report describes the evaluation of Title VII's programs from FY 1985 through FY 1989. The evaluation includes an investigation of the effectiveness of the programs in increasing the recruitment and retention of nurses.

TitleMain.Title: Review of federal/state medical waste management
TitleMain.OtherInformation: [microform] / C. C. Lee, G. L. Huffman.

Author.CollectiveName: Environmental Protection Agency (Cincinnati, OH). Risk Reduction Engineering Laboratory.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: The paper will discuss what has been learned as a result of the following recent activities: (1) EPAs/Risk Reduction Engineering Laboratorys (RRELs) state-of-the-art assessment of medical waste thermal treatment; (2) the four medical waste management workshops co-sponsored by EPAs RREL, OSW, and the California Air Resources Board; (3) the passage of the Medical Waste Tracking Act (MWTA) in 1988; (4) the two-year Demonstration Program required by the MWTA in the covered States; (5) the promulgation of medical waste incineration standards by several States; and (6) EPAs/Office of Solid Wastes (OSW's) submittal of their first Interim Report to Congress. Because of the information needed to support these activities, both the Federal Government and States have conducted various studies. The paper is to discuss what has been learned as a result of these studies.

TitleMain.Title: The midwives in the days of upheavals in Uganda -- "reflections of a practicing midwife"

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Tokyo, Japan, Japanese Nursing Association, Midwives' Division, 1990.
PublicationInfo.Place: Tokyo, Japan, Japanese Nursing Association, Midwives' Division,

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: A nurse midwife spoke of obstacles faced by rural midwives in Uganda during the violence in the late 1970s. During the civil war, some survivors lived temporarily in old sections of Mulago Hospital in Kampala. Most of the violence in the most turbulent years was centered in the 3 districts of Luwero, Mubende, and Mpigi located north and north west of Kampala. It was known as the Luwero Triangle. In 1980, it had an estimated population of 700,000. Between 1980-1986, 50,000-20,000 either simply died from disease or starvation or were massacred. The victims were usually women, children, and the elderly. Sometimes heavy artillery destroyed villages. Families often separated and people hid during the day regardless of the weather. Food and water were limited and when found they rarely were prepared in a sanitary manner. Women in labor either delivered the child themselves or other women and even men helped. All too often, however, complications arose. The people considered the professional midwife as an advisor, a leader, a decision maker, and a physician. Equipment used during deliveries often included a cloth or rag, a string or banana fiber, a matchbox, and a razor blade. Midwives received the newborn from a squatting mother. Maternal depletion syndrome and other complications often arose in the puerperium. 1 case involved a mother who bled to death following placenta previa but her child lived. 4 years later her husband was killed. They had 7 children. Another case included a husband who delivered twins. His wife experienced severe hemorrhage. Sensing his and her other 6 children's danger, she told them to seek safety. Neither the mother nor the twins had been seen since. Midwives in Uganda have begun to rehabilitate their profession by hosting workshops and seminars, updating the midwife educational curriculum to include management of emergency deliveries, and offering training.

TitleMain.Title: People v. Adams.

Author.CollectiveName: California. Court of Appeal, Third Appellate District (San Joaquin County).

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Slip Opinion, No. C003631, Superior Court No. 39257, 1990.
PublicationInfo.Publisher: Slip Opinion, No. C003631, Superior Court No. 39257,

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: Following an altercation, the defendant, Vernon Adams, shot the victim, Clarence Hughes, in what Adams claimed was self-defense. Hughes knew he would die from the gunshot wound and chose not to prolong his life through artificial life-support. The trial court admitted Hughes' statements as dying declarations. On appeal, Adams asserted that the state had permitted Hughes to die before he had had an opportunity to cross-examine Hughes' statements. The California Court of Appeal held that because the right to reject life-sustaining procedures outweighed the right to confrontation, the state had no power, and consequently no duty, to keep a dying witness alive against his will.

TitleMain.Title: National plan to enhance aviation safety through human factors improvements

Author.CollectiveName: Aviation Safety/Automation Program Conference

Abstract.AbstractText: The purpose of this section of the Plan is to establish a development and implementation strategy plan for improving safety and efficiency in the Air Traffic Control (ATC) system. These improvements will be achieved through the proper applications of human factors considerations to the present and future systems. The program will have four basic goals: prepare for the future system through proper hiring and training; develop controller work station team concept (managing human errors); understand and address the human factors implications of negative system results (NMACs, incursions, etc.); define the proper division of responsibilities and interactions between the human and the machine in ATC systems.

TitleMain.Title: Sight testing and the role of optometry

TitleOther.TitleAlternate: Discussion paper series (University of York. Centre for Health Economics) ;

Author.CollectiveName: University of York. Centre for Health Economics.

PublicationInfo.Imprint: York : University of York, Centre for Health Economics, 1990.
PublicationInfo.Publisher: University of York, Centre for Health Economics,

Abstract.AbstractText: The optical services market has been altered substantially by government legislation over the past six years. Further deregulation has been proposed which would alter the content and structure of the eye test, resulting in a two-tier test. This would split the refractive sight test, aimed at establishing the need for optical appliances, from the eye examination, aimed at detecting signs of abnormality and eye disease. In order to explore the potential consequences of such action, the current role of the optometrist in sight-testing is examined, with particular reference to two serious eye diseases, glaucoma and diabetic retinopathy. The potential effects of deregulation on both resource use and quality of life are considered in relation to these disorders, and the important role of the optometrist in both the detection of (often asymptomatic) eye disease and also in monitoring disease at the post-diagnosis stage is examined. The report concludes that legislation which alters the structure and content of the sight test would have potentially detrimental effects on both resource use in the health care sector and quality of life for patients.

TitleMain.Title: Tort reform and the obstetric access crisis : the case of the WAMI states

TitleOther.TitleAlternate: Rural health working paper series ; no. 8

Author.OtherInformation: Department of Family Medicine, University of Washington.

Author.CollectiveName: WAMI Rural Health Research Center.

Abstract.AbstractText: The states of Washington, Alaska, Montana, and Idaho (WAMI) have all experienced declines in the proportion of physicians offering obstetric services during the last few years, a decline precipitated primarily by rising medical malpractice premiums. One of the responses to the problem of rising liability premiums has been the passage of extensive tort reform legislation. This study presents the results of recent studies of physicians' obstetric practices in all four of the WAMI states and summarizes the major changes in tort legislation and regulation that have occurred in these states. The majority of general and family physicians in the WAMI region no longer provide obstetrical care; by contrast, over 80 percent of the obstetrician-gynecologists in the WAMI states are still practicing obstetrics. Despite the fact that only a minority of family physicians are still active in obstetrics, most rural family physicians in all four states still deliver babies. However, the majority of physicians in all four states limit the amount of care they will provide to those covered by Medicaid, which suggests that significant barriers to care exist for the medically indigent. All four states have adopted significant tort reforms, and the pattern of the reforms is quite similar throughout the region. Despite these changes in the legal environment, the cost of malpractice premiums and concerns over the likelihood of being sued continue to limit the number of physicians willing to provide obstetrical care. It is likely that tort reform has been effective in decreasing the rate at which physicians have given up obstetric practice, but the legislative changes to date have not eliminated the problem of impaired access to obstetric care for vulnerable population groups.

TitleMain.Title: Recombinant erythropoietin : payment options for Medicare. Special rept

Author.CollectiveName: United States. Office of Technology Assessment.

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Washington, DC : Office of Technology Assessment., 1990.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: The special report evaluates alternative payment policies that Medicare might use to pay for recombinant erythropoietin. Identifies nine options and analyzed their implications across several dimensions: quality of care, access to care, costs and efficiency, equity, technological innovation, and administrative feasibility. Extending coverage to self-administration of the biologic would improve access to care, especially for home dialysis patients, but would raise expenditures of the Medicare program.

For each topic, the study provides an overview of the number of pertinent laws passed in 1990 and the states that enacted them. TitleMain.Title: Medicare's disproportionate share adjustment for hospitals

Author.CollectiveName: United States. Congressional Budget Office.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: Under provisions of the Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1985, the Congress required the Congressional Budget Office (CBO) to study the adjustment in Medicare's Prospective Payment System (PPS) that provides additional payments to hospitals treating a disproportionately large share of low-income patients. In response to that mandate, the report addresses the following topics: the distribution of payments to hospitals that result from the so-called 'disproportionate share' adjustment; the relationship between serving a disproportionately large share of low-income patients and hospitals' recent costs of treating Medicare patients; and the effects on hospitals, especially disproportionate share hospitals, of options for the disproportionate share adjustment.

TitleMain.Title: Medical expert handbook (Social Security Administration, Washington, DC. Office of Hearings and Appeals)

Author.CollectiveName: United States. Social Security Administration. Office of Hearings and Appeals.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: Medical Experts (MEs) are physicians and mental health professionals who provide impartial expert opinion at the hearing level on claims under title XVI and title XVIII of the Social Security Act. All MEs on Office of Hearings and Appeals (OHA) Regional Office rosters will receive a copy of the new handbook when they attend their orientation session. The handbook describes the concepts and terms of medical evaluation as defined in the Social Security Act, regulations, rulings and policy issuances, and clarifies the ME's role in the disability decision-making process. In addition to serving as an adjunct to the orientation session, MEs may use the handbook as a prehearing desk reference when Administrative Law Judges request them to participate in the hearing process.

TitleMain.Title: Incentive arrangements offered by health maintenance organizations and competitive medical plans to physicians. Report to Congress. Volume 1. Final rept

Author.CollectiveName: United States. Dept. of Health and Human Services. Office of the Assistant Secretary for Planning and Evaluation.

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Washington, DC : Office of the Assistant Secretary for Planning and Evaluation, 1990.
PublicationInfo.Publisher: Office of the Assistant Secretary for Planning and Evaluation,

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: The Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1986 amended the Social Security Act to prohibit a hospital or an eligible organization with a risk-based contract under Medicare, or an entity with a contract under Medicaid, from knowingly making incentive payments to a physician. These incentive payments act as an inducement to reduce or limit services provided to persons who are under the direct care of the physician, and who are entitled to benefits under Medicare or Medicaid. The project addressed incentive arrangements offered by health maintenance organizations (HMOs) and competitive medical plans (CMPs) to physicians. The report reviews the activities that led to the General Accounting Office (GAO) investigation in 1986 of hospital physician incentive plans; chronicles the evolution of risk-contracting in the Medicare program; discusses program experience in dealing with problems that have arisen under Medicare's prepaid health plan option; and includes information on existing incentive arrangements.

TitleMain.Title: Report to Congress : administratively necessary days

Author.CollectiveName: Urban Institute.
United States. Health Care Financing Administration. Office of Research and Demonstrations.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: Section 9305(e) of the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1986, Public Law 99-509, required the Department of Health and Human Services to study whether the Medicare prospective payment system (PPS) is causing financial hardship for hospitals that have difficulty discharging patients because of limited access to the nursing home market. The specific mandate was to determine whether payments should be made to hospitals for administratively necessary days (ANDs), separate from the diagnosis related group and outlier payments. For the purpose of the study, the legislation defines AND as 'a day of continued inpatient hospital stay, for an individual entitled to benefits under Part A of title XVIII of the Social Security Act, necessitated by a delay in obtaining placement for the individual in a skilled nursing facility.' The report confirms that some hospitals incur delays in discharging patients to nursing homes. It is a very complex issue but, in general, discharge delays due to insufficient accessibility of nursing home beds can be attributed to four major factors: area nursing home bed shortages; low proportions of area nursing homes beds certified to provide skilled nursing care; stringency of Medicaid nursing home reimbursement; and/or areas where the marginal cost of Medicare patients is not lower than the average facility cost and the Medicare payment ceiling.

TitleMain.Title: Report to Congress : impact of the Medicare hospital prospective payment system. 1987 annual report

Author.CollectiveName: United States. Health Care Financing Administration. Office of Research and Demonstrations.

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Baltimore, MD : Health Care Financing Administration, 1990.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: The Social Security Amendments of 1983 and the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1986 (OBRA 86) mandated a series of six annual reports on the impact of the Medicare Prospective Payment System (PPS). The reports are required to describe and assess the impact of PPS on beneficiaries, classes of hospitals, other providers, and other payers for inpatient hospital services. Special concern was expressed about post-hospital care. This is the fourth in a series of six annual reports by the Department of Health and Human Services. The two objectives of the report are: (1) to provide an update on the status of PPS as of 1987 and, (2) report on the studies of PPS impact that have been completed since the third report was prepared. The major source of data for the report is the Medicare statistical system. Among the major findings are: (1) Medicare benefit payments for inpatient hospital care increased by 3.7 percent in FY 1987, the smallest increase in the history of the Medicare program and; (2) total days of inpatient care per 1,000 Medicare aged beneficiaries continued to decline in 1986.

TitleMain.Title: Medical assistance facility certification criteria (revised)
TitleMain.OtherInformation: [microform] / J. B. Christianson, I. S. Moscovice, G. Tao.

Author.CollectiveName: University of Minnesota. Division of Health Services Research and Policy.
United States. Health Care Financing Administration.

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Minneapolis, MN : University of Minnesota. Division of Health Services Research and Policy, 1990.
PublicationInfo.Publisher: University of Minnesota. Division of Health Services Research and Policy,

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: The study provides detailed descriptive information on two proposed alternatives to rural hospitals: the Medical Assistance Facility (MAF) and the Rural Primary Care Hospital (RPCH). The data show that hospitals identified under each alternative are quite different than the 'average' rural hospital. They provide more limited services, have fewer beds, and are more likely to be publicly owned. They are located in counties with small proportions of elderly residents and Medicare patients represent a smaller percentage of their total patient census, but they are more likely to be certified to provide long-term care. Although they provide care using as many, or more, personnel per bed than other rural hospitals, they are much less likely to be accredited by the Joint Commission for the Accreditation of Health Care Organizations (JCAHO). MAF/PCH qualifiers tend to be located in counties with higher per capita incomes than is the case for other rural hospitals. Also, they are disproportionately located in the west north central and mountain census regions.

TitleMain.Title: Durable medical equipment competitive bidding demonstration. Simulation of the impact of OBRA 1987 on reimbursement of durable medical equipment. Final rept
TitleMain.OtherInformation: [microform] / W. D. Marder, D. C. Reck.

Author.CollectiveName: Abt Associates.
United States. Health Care Financing Administration. Office of Research and Demonstrations.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: The report presents an analysis of the effects of the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1987 (OBRA 87) on Medicare total allowed charges for durable medical equipment (DME) during 1989, the first year the new rules applied. Using different assumptions regarding inflation rates and changes in supplier billing, the report shows that allowed charges could range from a reduction of 4 percent to an increase of 13.4 percent. The report also shows that the 1989 fee schedules still reflected widely varying rates for the same or similar items in different carrier jurisdictions, although that variance is significantly reduced if fee schedules below the 10th percentile and above the 90th percentile are not considered. Overall the analysis shows that unless suppliers react to published fee schedule amounts and begin billing at those limits, that the OBRA changes have little impact on Medicare spending for DME. It also appears that the growth in DME reimbursement is more from a changing age structure for elderly beneficiaries than from large increases in prices or increased utilization per beneficiary.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: Hostage-taking has become an almost everyday occurrence in many parts of the world. Desperate relatives and self-promoting politicians make the headlines; this documentary is devoted to the hostages. The program presents the case histories of four hostages who were released and asks them some difficult questions. The ex-hostages relive their experiences, and the manner of answering the interviewer's questions, as much as the answers themselves, provide insight into the psychology of being held hostage.

TitleMain.Title: Health and revolution : the Nicaraguan experience

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: This book traces the 10-year development of health services in Nicaragua within the context of revolution, poverty, debt, and natural disasters. The book is based on the lives of Nicaraguans, statistical data, and studies. It is structured in chapters that progress from a description of chaotic and crisis conditions prior to 1979, to the health-service-for-all approach during 1979-83, and to service expansion and crisis containment during 1984-90. A number of chapters were co-authored by a variety of people. Chapters focus on the following topics: the organization of health services, community participation, mass mobilizations, the health impact of the "Contra" war, hospital services, ambulatory care, AIDS, women's health, child survival, health professionals, medical education, medicines and medical equipment, health financing, and health in a survival economy. The last chapter describes the Nicaraguan health model. The effort to expand health services rapidly led to mistakes, but the initiative in 1988 aimed to rapidly reduce infant mortality despite a severe economic crisis and war. The 1980 Sandanista literacy campaigns helped women understand the causes of health and disease, people gained access to basic utilities and sanitation, and food was subsidized. It was learned that well-designed health programs, targeted at specific groups and implemented with wide-spread community participation, can achieve impressive results. The health model is an "eclectic" mix of public and private services, community participation, health education, extensive rural primary health care networks, and hospitals. The health system receives support from international donors and religious and political groups. Foreign aid may be crucial to successful development in Nicaragua and to unification.

TitleMain.Title: Family practitioner committees and their customers

TitleOther.TitleAlternate: Discussion paper series (University of York. Centre for Health Economics) ;

Author.CollectiveName: University of York. Centre for Health Economics.

PublicationInfo.Imprint: York : University of York, Centre for Health Economics, 1989.
PublicationInfo.Publisher: University of York, Centre for Health Economics,

Abstract.AbstractText: This paper illustrates some of the ways in which the Family Practitioner Committees will have to change in order to bring about their transformation from the 'passive paying agency' into the 'active manager of customer interests' when the proposals from the recent White Paper, 'Working for Patients', become law. We were asked to examine what was happening in the area of 'consumer relations' within the National Health Service by the Department of Health. Part of this work has involved our surveying all the Family Practitioner Committees in England and Wales. This paper presents the results of our survey, examining some of the pioneering work carried out by a handful of FPCs to enhance consumer relations and highlighting the enormous amount of work that has yet to be done to ensure that providers and financiers really know what customers want from their local Health Service. All 98 FPCs were written to for information about customer relations' initiatives and 60 replies were received. Of these only nine FPCs had carried out work in the area of customer relations, ten planned to do so and one had work in progress. The number of active FPCs varied notably by region, there was evidence of more work being done in the northern half of the country than in the south. The responses indicated that very little work was being undertaken to test the quality of the service provided by contractors (e.g. GPs) to FPCs. Most of the work was either a public relations exercise or surveys of accessibility. The results appeared to have little or no impact upon the policy of the FPCs. If FPCs are to become active managers of primary care services, radical changes in their practices with regard to customer relations are essential and long overdue.

TitleMain.Title: Addressing barriers to rural perinatal care : a case study of the Access to Maternity Care Committee in Washington State
TitleMain.OtherInformation: / D. Schleuning, G. Rice, R. A. Rosenblatt.

TitleOther.TitleAlternate: Rural health working paper series ; v. 1, no. 5

Author.OtherInformation: Inland Empire Perinatal Center, Spokane, Washington.

Author.CollectiveName: WAMI Rural Health Research Center.

Abstract.AbstractText: Access to obstetrical services in rural areas has deteriorated in recent years, as a large number of rural physicians have discontinued obstetrical practice. In Washington State, one response to this access crisis has been the establishment of the Access to Maternity Care Committee (AMCC), an ad hoc group composed primarily of private obstetrical providers and representatives of state government responsible for the delivery of health care to women and children. The major objective of the AMCC is to improve access to obstetrical services for socially vulnerable women, both rural inhabitants and the medically indigent. The Committee has been successful in serving as a forum in which to resolve many of the administrative problems that have arisen between private obstetrical providers and the state's Medicaid program, the major source of payment for the one-third of pregnant women who are medically indigent. Building upon the trust that developed in working together, the AMCC served as one of the major forces in persuading the state legislature to substantially expand its investment in perinatal care by increasing Medicaid eligibility, raising provider reimbursement, and improving social services for pregnant women. Such ad hoc coalitions between the private and public sector may be quite effective in addressing obstetrical access problems in other states.

TitleMain.Title: Pour une strategie de formation des prestataires de service de SMI/BEF au Tchad

TitleOther.TitleAlternate: Training strategy for health personnel in MHC/FP in Chad.

PublicationInfo.Imprint: N'Djamena, Chad, Republique du Tchad, Ministere de la Sante Publique, Secretariat d'Etat, Direction Generale, Unite, Travail Progres, [, 1988.
PublicationInfo.Place: N'Djamena, Chad, Republique du Tchad, Ministere de la Sante Publique, Secretariat d'Etat, Direction Generale, Unite, Travail Progres, [,

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: Family planning in Chad is defined as a policy in child-spacing; it is a struggle against sexually transmitted diseases and infertility by culture-specific methods to promote the health of mothers and children. A national program in maternal and child health and family planning (SMI/BEF) is badly needed in Chad to respond to the overwhelming health needs of the population. Severe socioeconomic and health related problems from years of war and natural calamities have destroyed the health infrastructure and account for the large numbers of health professionals that emigrated during this period. The per capita income went from US$120 in 1972 to US$37 in 1982; 23% of the population (5 million) are women in the reproductive ages; the general mortality rate is 20.9/1000; the infant mortality rate is 210/1000; there is 1 nurse per 4439 inhabitants and 1 physician for 70,959 inhabitants. From 1985-88 230 Chadians received training in family planning from US donor organizations (USAID, JHPIEGO, OPTIONS, PATHFINDER, CAFS, Columbia University). Chad's health needs remain limitless because there are few well-trained personnel in MCH/FP. The 1 major national referral center in N'Djamena, the Assiam Vantou Center, only has 35 health personnel, 4 of whom are trained in MCH/FP. Throughout Chad, the Ministry of Public Health has 18 regional posts and 16 branches. There are 78 auxiliary health personnel in these sites, and only 6 are trained in MCH/FP. A short-term strategy includes integrating family planning into the curriculum of the National School for Public Health and Social Affairs; training trainers of trainers and to continue increasing the numbers of health personnel for family planning. Charts outline a breakdown of types of health personnel by regions and provinces in Chad.

NLMCatalogRecord.GeneralNote: Conference sponsored by Chad, Ministry of Public Health, U.S. Agency for International Development [USAID], the Options Project, United Nations Population Fund [UNFPA] and the International Planned Parenthood Federation [IPPF], Africa Region.

TitleMain.Title: Health care in a pluralistic society : Lebanon, past and present

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Lanham, Maryland, University Press of America, 1988.
PublicationInfo.Place: Lanham, Maryland, University Press of America,

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: Despite political, religious and ethnic pluralism in Lebanon, the standard of medical education and health care were, until the 1st civil war in 1975, among the highest in the Arab Middle East. Nonetheless, ensuing wars have done much to erode its previously high standards. Until Lebanon ends its wars and rids itself of political extremism, health care will continue to suffer. Because of the wars, the primary health care and preventive medicine programs have been displaced by the need to care for the injured and the practice of therapeutic medicine. The wars have also effected the medical education system, which had high standards and was based on western ideas under the influence of The American University of Beirut and the Universite Saint Joseph. Before the wars, numerous private and international agencies cooperated with the government in setting up health programs on a scientific and industrialized fashion. Quality of health manpower was high, with many physicians returning from abroad after studies and training, and superspecialization was evident resulting in Lebanon advancing medicine and surgery: 1st Arab country to perform open heart surgery and kidney transplants. The beginning of the 1975 civil was was marked by increased political fragmentation, a very large Palestinian refugee community living with their own governing structure and services and a large increase in the Moslem population. Government and private projects came to a standstill, 1.5 million people were displaced, over 65,000 men, women and children were killed, and problems developed with water supply, sewers, roads and public utilities. Health care, among other vital services, has continued to deteriorate. The escalating confrontations between Israel and the Palestinians came to a head in the Israeli invasion of 1982 which resulted in the expulsion of the Palestinian fighters by Israel from Beirut and at a later date, their expulsion from Tripoli by the Syrians. Security has replaced government provision of health services in the preventative care area. Medical therapy and medicine is now brought like bread and food. 1/4 more hospital beds are needed and the government has had to contract with private hospitals to insure the availability of hospital beds for treatment of war casualties.

NLMCatalogRecord.Host: Modern and traditional health care in developing societies: conflict and co-operation, edited by Christine I. Zeichner

TitleMain.Title: The impact on health in Mozambique of South African destabilization

PublicationInfo.Imprint: New York, New York, Columbia University, 1988.
PublicationInfo.Place: New York, New York, Columbia University,

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: Since 1982, South African destabilization has had a devastating effect on the primary health care system in Mozambique, through the deliberate destruction of health facilities and the effects of war and displacement on the population. By 1986, 213 peripheral health posts had been destroyed, and 382 others forced to close, representing 31% of the total network. Despite reopenings and continued expansion, the total fell from 1416 to 1326. 4 rural hospitals have been forced to close. 2 million people have lost access to primary health care. Medical transportation has been disrupted, and medical supplies destroyed. At least 21 health care workers have been killed, and 44 kidnapped. Many foreign physicians working in Mozambique have fled. While the total number of deaths due to the war is unknown, infant mortality may be as high as 50% by age 5 in some regions. Most of the dead and injured adults are civilians, and the elderly are killed indiscriminately. Hospitals are strained by the volume of wounded people. Low food production, displacement and infections have combined to increase the incidence of malnutrition. Relief efforts, including food aid trucks, have been attacked. War has produced ideal conditions for the spread of infectious diseases. Children are deprived of schooling, and family and community life are disrupted. 1/3 of children have lost or been separated from 1 or both parents. The costs of the lost lives are incalculable, but US$21 million in buildings and US$3.8 million in supplies have been lost during a time of economic crisis. Despite this grim picture, the health system continues to function, to rebuild, and to train new workers.

NLMCatalogRecord.GeneralNote: Paper presented at the Third Workshop of the Project on Poverty, Health and the State in Southern Africa, sponsored by The Committee on Health in Southern Africa, Medico International, Columbia University, held at Columbia University, May 13-15, 1988.
NLMCatalogRecord.Host: Women's health and apartheid: the health of women and children and the future of progressive primary health care in Southern Africa, edited by Marcia Wright, Zena Stein and Jean Scandlyn

TitleMain.Title: Can you still get polio?

Author.CollectiveName: WGBH (Television station : Boston, Mass.)

PhysicalDescription.Extent: 1 videocassette (58 min.) : sd., col. with b&w ; 1/2 in. + 1 guide.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: No more than ten cases of polio are reported annually in the United States today. These few cases, however, are directly linked to the orally administered Sabin vaccine which uses a live virus culture. No cases of polio have been reported due to the administration of the Salk vaccine which does not use a live virus. In interviews with Jonas Salk and Albert Sabin, the advantages and disadvantages of the two methods of immunization are explored.

TitleMain.Title: Issues in reproductive health law in the Commonwealth
TitleMain.OtherInformation: / by Rebecca J. Cook and Bernard M. Dickens.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: The present report, designed for the 1986 Meetings of Commonwealth Ministers of Law and Health, addresses general issues in Commonwealth reproductive health law. An initial overview of reproductive health services includes consideration of maternal and child mortality and their impact on family life. Succeeding chapters address a variety of legal aspects of contraception, sterilization and abortion. Also addressed are legal aspects of responses to infertility. Prominent issues in contraception include the House of Lords' decision on adolescent access to contraceptive services in the widely discussed English Gillick case, and legal aspects of newer forms of contraception. Sterilization issues include discussion of the growing Commonwealth case law on legal consequences of sterilization failure. Abortion issues include new legislation in Barbados, Bermuda, Ghana and Montserrat and litigation in, for instance, Canada and Australia. Infertility is a growing problem in all parts of the Commonwealth. Causes of infertility are discussed, followed by consideration of legislation and proposals for legislation on human artificial reproduction. The Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women is considered to warrant special attention by the audiences addressed in this report. Discussion draws attention to the Commonwealth Secretariat's accession kit developed to facilitate membership in this Convention by Commonwealth countries which have yet to make a legal commitment to its principles and reporting mechanisms. The call for equal access to health including family planning services must be heard by Law Ministers and Health Ministers alike.

TitleMain.Title: Malaria control activities in Nicaragua : innovations in community participation

Abstract.AbstractText: Reasons for selected failures of malaria eradication campaigns in Latin America are reviewed. Emphasis on urban, curative, hospital-based care throughout Central America preempted the development of preventive health activities by motivated community members via volunteer for health tasks. With changes in the orientation towards primary health care and the decentralization of health administration following 1979 in Nicaragua, it became possible to involve the population en masse in health tasks. Community participation for malaria control developed through both short and long term activities, including peri-domestic cleanups, sanitation campaigns, mass drug administrations, and expanded diagnosis and treatment of symptomatic individuals. Members of newly formed community organizations and employed literate youth have shown the greatest motivation for participation in volunteer health activities, but more traditional community groups have also become involved in the volunteer health activities. Approximately 10% of the population took part in antimalarial activities during a national mass drug administration campaign in 1981. This campaign led to a reduction from expected levels of 7700 malaria cases recorded during a period of 4 months, after which cases returned to baseline levels. Peri-domestic clean-up activities demonstrated a salutory effect by reducing by 1500 the number of recorded cases from expected levels. The reduction in cases related to peri-domestic cleanups was noted only for a duration of 1 month. These campaigns led to expanded health education, epidemiologic vigilance and a widened search for cases in local communities throughout the country. These on-going local activities over a period of 2 years reduced malaria incidence by more than 50% despite a 70% decline in the amount of intradomiciliary sprayings carried out. Success of these local activities, however, appears to require social stability and effective administrative follow-up. Where such stability no longer exists because of the current war in Nicaragua, malaria incidence has risen. Yielding 1600 cases above expected levels for the period January 1983-July 1984. During this same period, there is a reduction of 2500 in the recorded number of cases from expected levels in areas not subject to direct military attack.

NLMCatalogRecord.GeneralNote: Doctoral dissertation, School of Public Health, Columbia University, April, 1985.

TitleMain.Title: Family planning, the Lebanese experience. A study on the Lebanese Family Planning Association

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: As of 1984, Lebanon had not yet formulated a clear and specific population policy because laws existed against contraception and political differences among the various ethnic groups also existed which culminated in a civil war. Nevertheless the government condoned the creation of the Lebanese Family Planning Association (LFPA) in August 1969 and its activities. The government also helped spread family planning through its own institutions such as the Ministry of Health and the Office of Social Development. Further some of LFPA's staff members have been part of the government itself. LFPA conducted a survey in June 1975 in Zahrani in rural south Lebanon and it showed that the people wished to limit their fertility, but could not since birth control was not available. Therefore LFPA established the 1st Community Based Family Planning Services Program in Zahrani which later spread to other villages. Wasitas (field workers) served as the major means of providing birth control and information to the women. They emphasized child spacing. The wasitas also served as a major adaptive and indigenous agent of social change and development. Initially they underwent intensive training lasting at least 1 week, but in 1979, LFPA hosted annual 1 month training sessions. The wasitas use of traditional communication methods resulted in not only an increase of contraceptive use, but also in meeting the elemental needs of the women for psychological comfort and self reliance. In some instances, however, some wasitas resorted to deception in encouraging the most uneducated women to use birth control because of strong incentives, e.g., the wasita received 50% of the money earned for the sale of each contraceptive. LFPA needed to reassess those measures which lead to possible encroachment of the dignity and freedom of choice of the women villagers.

NLMCatalogRecord.GeneralNote: Master's thesis, American University of Beirut, 1984 Jul.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: The following medico-legal recommendations of the 6th Commonwealth Health Ministers Meeting in November 1980 are discussed: 1) countries should provide for a jurisdiction to have at least a "developed" law, either by legislation or through an executive statement, 2) laws relating to approved contraceptive measures should be clearly exempted from the scope of laws relating to abortion, 3) lawful abortion should include at the minimum preservation of life and physical and mental health, 4) abortion services should be rendered by adequately qualified personnel, 5) consideration should be given to accomodating abortion primarily in laws focusing not upon crime and punishment but upon health and welfare, 6) maintain a dialogue between doctors and lawyers on legislation and medical practice, 7) regional groups and their secretariats should support the above activities, 8) the Secretariat should encourage discussion of issues relating to the medical termination of pregnancy at meetings of Health and Law Ministers, and 9) the Secretariat should continue to disseminate information on the legal and medical aspects of abortion, provide technical assistance to governments requesting help, and provide support in this area. Countries which have at least developed their laws are Belize, Seychelles, New Zealand, Hong Kong, Zimbabwe, Vanuatu (formerly New Hebrides), and those which have proposed amendments in the abortion law are Barbados, England, Nigeria, and Australia. The authors also discuss the extent to which Commonwealth governments have exempted contraceptives from the scope of laws relating to abortion, how Commonwealth governments have incorporated newer technologies, what these governments have done to enable the delivery of abortion services by qualified personnel, and to which governments have accomodated abortion in laws focusing upon health and welfare. Many member countries recognize that women and men have a right to health care treatment outside the context of crime and punishment.
